fields.value: Gender representation and experiences of gender bias in coastal geoscience and engineering

authorName.value: Women in Coastal Geoscience and Engineering

authorAffiliation.value: Women in Coastal Geoscience and Engineering

datasetContactName.value: Women in Coastal Geoscience and Engineering

datasetContactAffiliation.value: Women in Coastal Geoscience and Engineering

dsDescriptionValue.value: This dataverse contains data on gender representation and experiences of gender bias in coastal geoscience and engineering in 2016. This includes data of gender representation on journal editorial boards, societies, and conference organisation committees. In addition, a survey was undertaken of perceptions, experiences and observations of gender bias. These data were compiled by Women in Coastal Geoscience and Engineering (www.womenincoastal.org).

fields.value: Women in Coastal Geoscience and Engineering

files.description: This spreadsheet that includes data gained in 2016 on gender representation in major recurring international conferences and societies in coastal geoscience and engineering (CGE).
files.label: coastal_geoscience_and_engineering_gender_in_conferences.xlsx

dataFile.description: This spreadsheet that includes data gained in 2016 on gender representation in major recurring international conferences and societies in coastal geoscience and engineering (CGE).

files.description: This spreadsheets is of gender representation in journal editorial boards in the remit of coastal geoscience and engineering (CGE) in 2016. These journals were identified in Scopus and gender was approximated manually by looking at journal websites.
files.label: coastal_geoscience_and_engineering_gender_in_journals.xlsx

dataFile.description: This spreadsheets is of gender representation in journal editorial boards in the remit of coastal geoscience and engineering (CGE) in 2016. These journals were identified in Scopus and gender was approximated manually by looking at journal websites.

files.description: This spreadsheet is on gender representation  in 2016 in societies in the remit of coastal geoscience and engineering. Societal data on gender was provided by the society, with the exception of CERF where gender information was manually identified from the list of members (where possible).
files.label: coastal_geoscience_and_engineering_gender_in_societies.xlsx

dataFile.description: This spreadsheet is on gender representation  in 2016 in societies in the remit of coastal geoscience and engineering. Societal data on gender was provided by the society, with the exception of CERF where gender information was manually identified from the list of members (where possible).

files.description: This spreadsheet contains survey results of perceptions of gender (in)equality, experiences/ observations of gender bias, and ideas for ways to address this. This survey was launched during the 14th International Coastal Symposium (ICS), held in Sydney, Australia on 6–11 March 2016. We invited conference attendees to fill in a paper-based version of the survey and to deposit it in a ballot box at the venue. This resulted in 37 responses. Following this, and to include non-attendees to the conference, we launched the survey online using Survey Monkey®, which ran from September 2016 until January 2017, resulting in an additional 277 responses. We publicised our request to fill the survey via the WICGE website, Twitter, Facebook pages, listservs and email, thus allowing us to obtain results that are not specifically linked to one conference in CGE.
files.label: coastal_geoscience_and_engineering_gender_survey_on_gender_bias.xlsx

dataFile.description: This spreadsheet contains survey results of perceptions of gender (in)equality, experiences/ observations of gender bias, and ideas for ways to address this. This survey was launched during the 14th International Coastal Symposium (ICS), held in Sydney, Australia on 6–11 March 2016. We invited conference attendees to fill in a paper-based version of the survey and to deposit it in a ballot box at the venue. This resulted in 37 responses. Following this, and to include non-attendees to the conference, we launched the survey online using Survey Monkey®, which ran from September 2016 until January 2017, resulting in an additional 277 responses. We publicised our request to fill the survey via the WICGE website, Twitter, Facebook pages, listservs and email, thus allowing us to obtain results that are not specifically linked to one conference in CGE.
